questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 5-week history of pain in his left thigh. The mother reports that her son fell from a ladder while playing with friends about a month and a half ago. He had a runny nose 3 weeks ago. He has no history of serious illness. He has reached all developmental milestones for his age. His immunizations are up-to-date. His 7-year-old brother has asthma. The patient is at 60th percentile for height and 65th percentile for weight. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a mild left-sided antalgic gait. The left groin is tender to palpation; abduction and internal rotation are limited by pain. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,800/mm3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a left femoral epiphysis that is smaller than the right with widening of the medial joint space on the left. The femoral head shows little discernible damage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Limited weight bearing and physical therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Femoral osteotomy is performed to realign the femoral head and keep it within the acetabulum. It is indicated for the treatment of patients with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease who are older than 6–8 years of age and have extensive damage to the femoral head or for those with disease classified as lateral pillar B or C. In older children, surgery is more beneficial because the bone formation capacity is often too limited to repair femoral head damage.

B) INCORRECT:

Casting and bracing are indicated in patients with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease who are younger than 6 years of age and have not benefited from prior conservative treatment. In patients with a worsening range of motion of the hip and increasing damage of the femoral head, casting and bracing are performed to keep the femoral head contained within the acetabulum.

C) INCORRECT:

Femoral head pinning is a surgical procedure in which internal fixation of the femoral head is achieved through the placement of one or two cannulated screws. This procedure is indicated for treating slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). Although SCFE also causes thigh pain, limping is only seen in late stages and the condition most commonly affects boys aged 10–16 years with obesity. Typical hip x-ray findings include a widened femoral epiphyseal plate with increased lucency and/or posteroinferior displacement of the femoral head in relation to the femoral neck.

D) CORRECT:

Conservative management with limited weight bearing and physical therapy is recommended for patients with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease who are younger than 6 years of age and have minimal or no damage to the femoral head on the initial x-ray. At this age, it is still possible that bone formation will repair the defect. Casting and bracing should only be considered if femoral head deformity starts to develop or range of motion worsens despite other conservative measures.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis of an 8-year-old girl (AP view; frog-leg position)

The right femoral epiphysis (E) is smaller than the left and its contour is flattened (arrow). The appearance is compatible with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. No sclerosis or cystic lucencies are seen. The acetabulum is not deformed.

E) INCORRECT:

Nafcillin is a beta-lactam antibiotic with activity against gram-positive bacteria, especially S. aureus, the most common cause of osteomyelitis. Although osteomyelitis causes thigh pain, it also manifests with tenderness at the site of infection, malaise, fever, and chills, which are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: Antalgic gait and hip pain with limited internal rotation and abduction of the hip should raise concern for Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, which most commonly affects boys aged 4–10 years. This patient's x-ray shows erosion of the femoral epiphysis with minimal damage to the femoral head.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a limp for the last 3 weeks. He has also had right hip pain during this period. The pain is aggravated when he runs. He had a runny nose and fever around a month ago that resolved with over-the-counter medications. He has no history of serious illness. His development is adequate for his age. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears healthy. He is at the 60th percentile for height and at 65th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an antalgic gait. The right groin is tender to palpation. Internal rotation and abduction of the right hip is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,900/mm3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm3. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An unstable proximal femoral growth plate is the underlying cause of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). A hip x-ray would show a widened femoral epiphyseal plate with increased lucency, and/or femoral head posteroinferior displacement in relation to the femoral neck. Additionally, SCFE most commonly affects obese males between 10–16 years of age, making a diagnosis of SCFE in this 7-year-old patient unlikely.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis ( AP view) of a 14-year-old boy

Widening of the right femoral growth plate (physis; blue overlay) is accompanied by inferior and medial displacement of the epiphysis (green overlay) on the femoral neck (red overlay), which is cranially positioned relative to the acetabulum. Widening of the right hip joint is also seen (indicated by double-arrows). The left femur is also abnormal, with a widened neck. A line (Klein line; dashed lines) along the lateral edge of the superior femoral neck on either side does not intersect the respective epiphysis.

GS: gonad shield

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis is caused by bacterial infection of a joint, and manifests with joint pain and a restricted range of motion. However, patients with septic arthritis usually have fever, an elevated leukocyte count, and a more acute disease course than seen in this patient. Additionally, septic arthritis is typically more painful than Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. While this child has a limp and pain while running, a patient with septic arthritis of the hip would typically avoid bearing weight on the affected side because of pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis of the hip may occur following a viral process such as an upper respiratory tract infection. The pain from transient synovitis of the hip usually resolves within approx. 7 days and is unlikely to persist for 3 weeks. Moreover, unlike this child, patients with transient synovitis often have normal x-ray findings; ultrasound or MRI of the hip may show joint effusions in some patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is associated with immune-mediated synovial inflammation. Hip involvement occurs in 35–60% of patients with JIA and may manifest with hip pain and a limp that is characteristically worse early in the morning and improves with activity during the day. In this child, however, the pain is exacerbated by running. In addition, hip x-ray findings in the early stage of JIA are usually normal. Most importantly, this patient has had symptoms for about 3 weeks, and a diagnosis of JIA cannot be considered unless symptoms are present for more than 6 weeks.

E) CORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is characterized by necrosis of the femoral head due to poor vascular perfusion, which leads to hip pain and decreased ability to bear weight in the affected hip joint, as well as x-ray findings of joint space widening and femoral head flattening. The underlying pathophysiology is multifactorial, poorly understood, and often described as idiopathic avascular necrosis. Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease likely results from a combination of repetitive mechanical stress, microtrauma, and genetic predisposition. This patient should be treated nonsurgically with NSAIDs, physical therapy, and restriction of weight-bearing. Surgical treatment should be considered for children with extensive damage to the femoral head.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.
Image Description:

A. Normal anatomy: The femoral head is located in the center of the acetabulum.
B. Femoral head necrosis leads to lateral subluxation and displacement of the femoral head in the acetabulum.
C. Fractures and subsequent bone resorption result in an unstable femoral head. Lateral displacement puts a pathological strain on the femoral head when weight-bearing, which leads to deformities.
D. Hinge abduction: On hip abduction, the deformed lateral pillar of the femoral head impinges on the acetabular rim, preventing the femoral head from entering the acetabulum. This results in a hinge joint articulation instead of a ball-and-socket joint articulation at the hip.
questions.hint: Hip pain with limited internal rotation and abduction in addition to x-ray findings of joint space widening and femoral head flattening are consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, which most commonly affects boys aged 4–10 years.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of right hip pain that started that afternoon. His mother reports that he has also been limping since the pain developed. He says that the pain worsens when he moves or walks. He participated in a dance recital yesterday, but his mother believes that he was not injured at the time. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of nasal congestion and mild cough 10 days ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis and his grandmother has osteoporosis. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. His right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated. Examination shows no tenderness, warmth, or erythema. He is able to bear weight. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.3 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 8500/mm3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Ultrasonography of the right hip shows increased fluid within the joint. X-ray of the hips shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) are typically older than this patient, presenting at about 10–16 years of age. Additionally, SCFE occurs most often in obese boys, and this patient is at the 50th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Exam findings would also likely reveal external rotation along with flexion at the hip, not just external rotation and abduction. X-ray would show sclerotic epiphysis with joint widening when radiographic changes begin, but might be normal for the initial 4–6 months, meaning imaging alone is not enough to exclude SCFE in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

This otherwise healthy child presents with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection as well as hip pain and a limp for the past 24 hours, the combination of which suggests transient synovitis (TS). On exam, the right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated, a common finding in patients with hip pain as this position decreases joint capsule tension and the resulting pain. Patients with TS typically present with no (or low-grade) fever and normal laboratory findings (e.g., normal WBC count and ESR). TS can manifest with unilateral or bilateral joint effusion on ultrasonography, unlike septic arthritis, in which joint effusion is almost always a unilateral finding.

TS is a mild, self-limited disease and treatment is conservative with NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) and rest. If the effusion and/or the hip pain fails to resolve, follow-up imaging should be obtained to reassess for other conditions (e.g., Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease).

C) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is commonly seen in young patients who present with insidious-onset hip pain that may fluctuate with activity and a limp. X-ray findings may be normal in early disease and in later disease show medial joint space widening and an area of radiolucency around the femoral head indicative of subchondral fracture (crescent sign). While early LCPD cannot be entirely excluded, the patient's recent upper respiratory tract infection and the acute onset of symptoms make another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a child

The left femoral epiphysis (green overlay) is small, flattened (coxa plana), and sclerotic. The hip joint space is widened.

This appearance is consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. Early radiographic findings may include medial joint space widening and reduced bone density. Later, the femoral head may become small, fragmented, flattened, and sclerotic.

D) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is usually detected in newborns. Risk factors are female sex, breech delivery, and a family history of DDH. If not identified at birth, DDH can lead to progressive hip pain and difficulty walking very early in life. This patient has a normal birth history and has not had hip pain until this point. Moreover, unlike in this patient, an x-ray of a patient with DDH would likely be abnormal, with potential findings of acetabular dysplasia or femoral head dysplasia.
Image Description:

Pelvis and hips (AP view) of a 3 month old infant

Hilgenreiner’s line has been drawn horizontally connecting the inferior aspect of the ilium through the triradiate cartilages. The femoral heads should be below this line. The acetabular angle is measured between Hilgenreiner’s line and a line parallel to the acetabular roof.

The acetabular angle (or acetabular index) should be < 28 degrees at birth and should progressively decrease with hip maturation. At 3 months old, the normal acetabular angle is typically reported as in the range of 25 degrees, with a maximum measurement of 30 degrees. The acetabular angle in this patient is >30 degrees.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a recent infection, making him susceptible to septic arthritis of the hip. However, the index of suspicion for septic arthritis should be low in this case because the patient is able to bear weight and has normal vital signs and laboratory studies. Furthermore, a patient with septic arthritis of the hip would present with exquisite hip pain on palpation and the skin over the affected joint would be warm and erythematous.

F) INCORRECT:

Although osteomyelitis of the hip or femur can manifest with pain and limping, the affected area is typically tender and warm to palpation. In children, osteomyelitis also usually affects the long-bone metaphysis rather than the joints, which would be more likely affected in infants. Laboratory findings usually include an elevated WBC count and ESR. X-ray often shows no abnormalities during the first few days of infection but may reveal periosteal bone deposition.
questions.hint: This patient's effusion will likely improve over the next couple of weeks.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of right hip pain. His mother reports that he has been limping because the pain is aggravated by walking. The pain radiates to the right knee. He has not had any fever, cough, or a runny nose. He is otherwise healthy and has reached all developmental milestones for his age. Physical examination shows a restricted range of internal rotation as well as pain on flexion and abduction of the right hip. He has a right-sided antalgic gait. Hemoglobin concentration is 13.7 g/dL, leukocyte count is 7,900/mm3, and platelet count is 185,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is characterized by abnormal development of the acetabulum, which results in hip instability, hip pain, and a restricted range of abduction. However, this condition typically becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Late findings, which can be seen in children ∼ 18 months of age, include leg length discrepancy and a waddling or a Trendelenburg gait.

B) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by immune-mediated synovial inflammation and can involve the hip, which results in pain. However, pain associated with JIA is characteristically worse early in the morning and improves with activity during the day. This patient's pain is exacerbated by walking. In addition, JIA is typically associated with intermittent fever and elevated inflammatory markers, including leukocyte count.

C) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is characterized by inflammation of the hip joint capsule and is a common cause of acute hip pain among children (peak incidence of 3–8 years of age). However, this condition is typically associated with a recent viral infection. This patient has no evidence of current or recent infection (no fever, cough, runny nose, or leukocytosis). In addition, symptoms of transient synovitis generally improve within 24 hours and resolve within 2 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease is characterized primarily by anterior knee pain due to repetitive strain (overuse of the quadriceps muscle) during periods of growth. It is not associated with hip pain or a restricted range of motion of the hip joint. In addition, it more commonly affects older boys (peak incidence of 9–14 years of age).

E) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis is caused by bacterial infection of a joint and typically manifests with joint pain and restricted range of motion. However, patients with septic arthritis usually have fever, leukocytosis, and a more acute disease course. In addition, although this patient does have an antalgic gait, septic arthritis of the hip joint typically results in severe pain that impairs weight bearing.

F) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is characterized by posterior and inferior displacement of the femoral epiphysis and can manifest with hip pain, referred knee pain, a restricted range of internal rotation of the hip, and an antalgic gait. Although acute presentations of SCFE (which are associated with < 3 weeks of symptoms) can occur, they are usually associated with trauma. Most presentations of SCFE are chronic and manifest with vague, intermittent symptoms across several weeks to months. Moreover, SCFE is most commonly seen in obese children who are 10–16 years of age.

G) CORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head and is due to rapid epiphyseal growth without adequate blood supply. LCPD most commonly manifests in boys 4–10 years of age with limping (due to a restricted range of internal rotation and abduction of the hip), and pain of the hip on flexion, abduction, and external rotation, sometimes projecting to the knee. This condition typically has an insidious onset and is not associated with fever or hematologic abnormalities. Its underlying pathophysiology is not fully understood, but it is likely multifactorial, arising from a combination of repetitive mechanical stress, microtrauma, and genetic predisposition.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Both femoral epiphyses show flattening (blue lines) and sclerosis with areas of fragmentation (examples indicated by arrows).

The appearance is consistent with avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphyses of the femoral heads.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition may have unremarkable pelvic radiographs in the first 3–6 months after onset. Early changes include joint space widening, sclerosis of the femoral head, and disparate femoral head sizes.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of right knee and thigh pain since starting basketball at his school 4 months ago. The pain worsens following basketball practice and games. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is 140 cm (4 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 43 kg (95 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/76 mm Hg. Physical examination in the supine position shows that the right knee is mildly flexed and the right leg externally rotated. There is no pain or restriction of the passive range of motion in the right knee but the patient resists passive extension and internal rotation of the hip joint. Palpation of the right knee and right hip does not show tenderness, swelling, or crepitus. There is no endpoint laxity when the tibia is pulled forward. Dorsalis pedis pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. The results of a complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are within reference ranges. An x-ray of the right knee shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An MRI can be obtained after a negative knee x-ray if there is still a concern for internal derangement (e.g., knee effusion secondary to a bone, cartilage, ligamentous, meniscus, or patellar injury), infection, or malignancy. This patient, however, despite knee pain, has a normal range of motion of the right knee without point tenderness, anterior laxity, edema, or other signs and symptoms that suggest knee pathology. Therefore, an MRI of the knee is not the most appropriate next step in management.

B) CORRECT:

In patients presenting with nonspecific knee pain and no findings to suggest knee pathology, hip pathology must be considered as a potential source of knee pain, especially in pediatric patients. In pediatric patients like this one, with limited extension and internal rotation of the hip joint, an x-ray of the hip must be promptly obtained to rule out slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), which requires immediate avoidance of weight-bearing and urgent surgical intervention. If the x-ray of the hip shows no findings to suggest SCFE (e.g., widening of the joint space, displacement of the femoral head posteriorly and inferiorly to the femoral neck), Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease must be considered because patients with this condition commonly have normal radiographs in the early course of the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Rest and ibuprofen therapy may be considered as supportive care for pain. However, in a patient with suspected referred pain, additional workup is indicated to exclude other conditions that might require urgent intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the lumbar spine can be considered if referred back pain is suspected. Referred back pain can be caused by L2–L5 and S1 radiculopathies, which can manifest with thigh and knee pain, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, radiculopathies are uncommon in children, and patients typically also present with back pain, which is not seen here. Patients with radiculopathies may also present with weakness of knee extension, hip flexion and adduction, and reduced patellar reflex, none of which this patient has.

E) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopy of the knee is most commonly indicated in patients with acute knee injuries, such as osteochondral fractures, meniscal lesions, and ligamentous tears. This patient, however, despite knee pain, has a normal range of motion of the right knee without point tenderness, anterior laxity, edema, or other signs and symptoms that suggest knee pathology. Therefore, arthroscopy of the knee is not the most appropriate next step in management.
questions.hint: This patient's history of chronic, nonspecific knee and thigh pain in combination with a normal knee examination and imaging findings suggests referred pain.

questions.text:
The parents of a 6-year-old boy report that he has been limping for about one month without any preceding injury. The limp has been worsening, and the boy has been complaining of intermittent pain in the medial aspect of his left thigh and knee. He is an otherwise healthy, active child with an unremarkable medical history, born via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery.
He is afebrile and has no deformity of the lower extremities or leg-length discrepancy. He has a limping gait. The left hip exhibits diminished internal rotation and abduction compared with the right hip, but there is no warmth, swelling, or tenderness.
Radiographs show normal alignment of the left hip but increased radiodensity of the capital femoral epiphysis.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis may cause symptoms similar to those of Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, but radiograph findings would be normal. Additionally, transient synovitis typically resolves within 2 weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis typically occurs in older children (average age of onset, 12.7 years), and displacement of the capital femoral epiphysis would be evident on a radiograph.

C) CORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, a process of idiopathic avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis, occurs most often in children aged 4 to 10 years, primarily boys. The cause remains unknown.

The presenting complaints are typically a limp and occasional pain in the hip, thigh, or knee. The patient usually has a diminished range of motion, specifically with internal rotation. Early in the disease course, radiographs may be normal or show increased radiodensity of the capital femoral epiphysis. As the disease progresses, radiographs will show fragmentation and lucencies of the capital femoral epiphysis or collapse of the femoral head.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a limp, decreased internal rotation and abduction of the hip, and radiodensity of the capital femoral epiphysis in a young school-age boy is Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia is typically recognized before 5 years of age, may manifest with a leg-length discrepancy, and would be associated with abnormal hip alignment on a radiograph.

E) INCORRECT:

Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis may cause symptoms similar to those of Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, but radiograph findings would be normal. A patient with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis would be unlikely to present with hip pain for one month and no other clinical symptoms.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy has had a right-sided limp and right-hip pain for 2 days, without associated fever or recent trauma. He had an upper respiratory infection 10 days before symptom onset, but a throat culture at that time was negative for streptococcal infection.
His vital signs are within normal limits. He holds his right hip abducted and externally rotated when he is supine, and he is not able to bear weight on his right leg. There is no local warmth or erythema, but he has limited motion with minimal internal rotation and complete resistance on adduction of the hip.
A complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein level are within normal limits.
What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is a chronic arthritis that cannot be diagnosed unless symptoms have persisted for at least 6 weeks.

B) CORRECT:

Transient synovitis, also known as postinfectious arthritis or toxic synovitis, can follow any viral infection and is a common cause of arthritis in children. The majority of cases occur during or after an extra-articular viral infection — often an undefined mild upper respiratory infection, although cases have also been described following infection with rubella virus, parvovirus B19, coxsackie virus, and other viruses.

Transient synovitis typically involves the joints of the lower limbs, commonly the hip. Baseline investigations including a complete blood count and inflammatory markers are usually unremarkable and are not always warranted. Patients usually recover from transient synovitis within 2 weeks in response to treatment with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications.

Key learning point: The most probable diagnosis in an afebrile child with a limp that developed after a streptococcus-negative upper respiratory infection and is associated with hip abduction and external rotation on examination is transient synovitis.

C) INCORRECT:

The differential diagnosis of acute monoarthritis in a child is broad, and septic arthritis should always be ruled out if a child appears toxic and has fever, significant pain, or elevation of inflammatory markers. In this case, the child is afebrile and has normal laboratory results; therefore, septic arthritis is not likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever and poststreptococcal reactive arthritis are unlikely in the absence of a positive test for streptococcal infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever and poststreptococcal reactive arthritis are unlikely in the absence of a positive test for streptococcal infection. Patients with acute rheumatic fever typically present with fever and a migratory polyarthritis.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl who plays soccer and basketball reports a limp that is worse after she plays, is associated with what she describes as an “achy feeling” in the right hip, and improves with rest. She has no mechanical symptoms and cannot recall any injury, illnesses, fever, or weight loss. She takes occasional ibuprofen for the hip pain.
She is currently afebrile and has a BMI at the 96th percentile. She has mild tenderness over the right anterior-superior iliac spine but no swelling, bruising, or erythema of the hip or bony pelvis. She has full passive range of motion of the right hip. No pain is elicited when the leg is gently rolled internally and externally with the hip in extension. Her back and knees are normal.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Reassure her that the symptoms are likely to resolve spontaneously without active management
Obtain anteroposterior and frog-leg lateral radiographs of the hip
Recommend scheduled ibuprofen for one week, and instruct her to return if she has not improved
Obtain an ultrasound of the hip
Measure a complete blood count with differential and a C-reactive protein level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient plays two running sports and has started to have pain during and after play, which indicates that she should rest. In a patient with apophysitis, management also includes analgesics and a short period of protection from weight-bearing with crutches.

B) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis for hip pain, a common pediatric musculoskeletal complaint, should include septic joint, apophysitis, inflammatory arthritis, slipped capital femoral epiphysis, and Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. An appropriate first step is to order anteroposterior and frog-leg lateral radiographs to rule out Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease and slipped capital femoral epiphysis. Although these conditions might be lower on the differential diagnosis, they might also require more emergent intervention than others.

This patient most likely has apophysitis, an overuse injury characterized by irritation, inflammation, and microtrauma at the apophysis. It is the most common cause of hip pain in adolescents and is unique to the skeletally immature. The apophysis is a secondary ossification center and the site of attachment for the muscle tendon. Because it is the weak point in the bone-tendon-muscle chain, it is easily injured with forceful contraction of the muscle (which can cause an avulsion injury) or with repetitive stress (which can cause apophysitis).

The hip and pelvis have multiple apophyses with large muscle attachments. The anterior-superior iliac spine is often injured in sports that involve a lot of running. In apophysitis, radiographs may be normal or may show widening of the apophysis. Management should include analgesics, a short period of protection from weight-bearing with crutches, and a gradual return to sports after pain-free range of motion is achieved.

Key learning point: The most appropriate imaging for an afebrile school-age child with hip pain is anteroposterior and frog-leg lateral radiographs of the hip.

C) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen and reassurance would be appropriate for a patient experiencing growing pains, but these pains tend to affect the shins, calves, and thighs, not the hips. Furthermore, they seldom occur during the day and do not affect sports performance.

D) INCORRECT:

An ultrasound of the hip is warranted if the patient has a painful hip, fever, and an ill appearance, raising suspicion for septic arthritis. The absence of fever or pain on the log-roll test makes a hip-joint effusion or a septic joint unlikely in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Laboratory evaluation for inflammatory arthritis is not warranted, as the patient has localized tenderness of the bony pelvis, an atypical presentation for juvenile arthritis.

questions.text:
A healthy 7-year-old boy presents with one week of a painless limp affecting his right leg. His parents recall no recent injury, illness, fever, or weight loss. His BMI is in the 50th percentile.
He is afebrile. The right knee appears normal. Log roll of the right hip causes guarding with decreased range of motion in internal rotation and abduction when compared to the left hip. There is no bony tenderness over the pelvis.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the right hip

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fever, ill appearance, or localized hip pain would be concerning for a septic joint.

B) INCORRECT:

Apophysitis is an overuse injury that is more common in adolescents and that can involve multiple points on the pelvic hip or foot. Hip pain due to apophysitis is characterized by point tenderness over the anterior superior iliac spine.

C) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis tends to occur in children ages 10 to 14 with obesity, is more common in boys, and causes hip or knee pain.

D) CORRECT:

Avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis (Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease) typically manifests as a painless limp in children, usually between the ages of 4 and 8 years, and is more common in boys than girls. Interruption of the blood supply to the capital femoral epiphysis is the cause of the necrosis, but the etiology is unknown.

Diagnosis is based on physical examination findings (antalgic gait, restriction of hip abduction, and decreased internal rotation of the leg) and on anteroposterior and frog-leg-lateral hip radiographs. Radiographs may be normal or may show increased density, fragmentation, ossification, or remodeling of the femoral head. In patients with normal radiographs but high suspicion, MRI of the hips should be performed, and patients with positive findings should be referred to an orthopedist. Bilateral involvement is seen in approximately 10% to 15% of patients and requires further investigation for hemoglobinopathies, endocrine disorders, or skeletal dysplasia.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a 7-year-old boy with a one-week history of a painless limp and decreased range of motion in hip internal rotation and abduction is avascular necrosis of the hip.

E) INCORRECT:

Stress fractures of the femoral neck are uncommon in children and cause a painful limp. The pain may be present in the hip, thigh, or groin and can be reproduced by asking the patient to hop on the affected leg.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because of mild pain in his right hip for the past 3 weeks. The pain radiates to the right knee and intensifies during physical activity, such as soccer practice. He is otherwise healthy and has reached all developmental milestones for his age. He was delivered vaginally in a breech position. Family history is unremarkable. He does not take any medications, and his vaccinations are up-to-date. He is 130 cm tall (4 ft 3 in; 25th percentile) and weighs 23 kg (51 lb; 15th percentile). His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 105/70mm Hg. Physical examination shows pain in the right hip on internal rotation. Range of motion of the hip and knee is normal. A pelvic x-ray shows joint space widening of the right hip. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly predicts a poor prognosis?

choices.text: Age at the onset of symptoms

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although some studies identify breech delivery as a risk factor for LCPD, there is no evidence that it has prognostic significance for this condition.

Breech delivery increases the risk of developmental dysplasia of the hip, which can manifest with hip pain that radiates to the knee. However, this symptom and other features (e.g., limited range of motion, leg length discrepancy, Trendelenburg gait) typically appear much earlier because hip damage occurs by the age of 2–3 years if the condition is not detected and treated during infancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Although LCPD is more common in boys than girls, female sex is associated with a poor prognosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Overweight rather than underweight is associated with a poor prognosis for LCPD.

D) INCORRECT:

Hip stiffness and limited range of motion reflect extensive damage to the femoral head and are associated with a poor prognosis. Knee pain radiating from the hip is a common feature of LCPD and is not a prognostic factor.

E) CORRECT:

Older age at onset (> 8 years) of LCPD is associated with a poor prognosis, likely due to the decreased ability of the acetabulum to adapt to the deformed femoral head. Other important factors that predict a poor prognosis include female sex, limited range of motion (especially abduction), and extensive femoral head damage or lateral pillar involvement. Surgical treatment is considered in patients with advanced disease or multiple factors for a poor prognosis. The primary goal of treatment is to keep the femoral head contained within the acetabulum.
questions.hint: In a child aged 4–10 years, hip pain that has an insidious onset and intensifies with physical activity and internal rotation in combination with joint space widening on x-ray, suggests Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD).

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a 2-week history of right hip pain. His mother reports that he has been limping because the pain is aggravated by walking. The pain radiates to the right knee. He has not had any fever, cough, or a runny nose. Physical examination shows a restricted range of internal rotation as well as pain on flexion and abduction of the right hip. He has a right-sided antalgic gait. Hemoglobin concentration is 13.7 g/dL, leukocyte count is 7,900/mm3, and platelet count is 185,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is characterized by abnormal development of the acetabulum, which results in hip instability, hip pain, and a restricted range of abduction. However, this condition typically becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Late findings, which can be seen in children ∼ 18 months of age, include leg length discrepancy and a waddling or a Trendelenburg gait.

B) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by immune-mediated synovial inflammation and can involve the hip, which results in pain. However, pain associated with JIA is characteristically worse early in the morning and improves with activity during the day. This patient's pain is exacerbated by walking. In addition, JIA is typically associated with intermittent fever and elevated inflammatory markers, including leukocyte count.

C) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is characterized by inflammation of the hip joint capsule and is a common cause of acute hip pain among children (peak incidence of 3–8 years of age). However, this condition is typically associated with a recent viral infection. This patient has no evidence of current or recent infection (no fever, cough, runny nose, or leukocytosis). In addition, symptoms of transient synovitis generally improve within 24 hours and resolve within 2 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is characterized by posterior and inferior displacement of the femoral epiphysis and can manifest with hip pain, referred knee pain, a restricted range of internal rotation of the hip, and an antalgic gait. Although acute presentations of SCFE (which are associated with < 3 weeks of symptoms) can occur, they are usually associated with trauma. Most presentations of SCFE are chronic and manifest with vague, intermittent symptoms across several weeks to months. Moreover, SCFE is most commonly seen in obese children who are 10–16 years of age.

E) CORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head and is due to rapid epiphyseal growth without adequate blood supply. LCPD most commonly manifests in boys 4–10 years of age with limping (due to a restricted range of internal rotation and abduction of the hip), and pain of the hip on flexion, abduction, and external rotation, sometimes projecting to the knee. This condition typically has an insidious onset and is not associated with fever or hematologic abnormalities. Its underlying pathophysiology is not fully understood, but it is likely multifactorial, arising from a combination of repetitive mechanical stress, microtrauma, and genetic predisposition.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Both femoral epiphyses show flattening (blue lines) and sclerosis with areas of fragmentation (examples indicated by arrows).

The appearance is consistent with avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphyses of the femoral heads.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition may have unremarkable pelvic radiographs in the first 3–6 months after onset. Early changes include joint space widening, sclerosis of the femoral head, and disparate femoral head sizes.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office with right hip pain that started that afternoon. His mother reports that he has also been limping since the pain developed. He says that the pain worsens when he moves or walks. He had an episode of nasal congestion and mild cough 10 days ago. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F). Physical examination reveals:

Slightly abducted and externally rotated right hip
Decreased active and passive range of motion of the right hip
Hypertonicity of the gluteus medius and piriformis muscles
No tenderness, warmth, or erythema of the right hip
Intact ability to bear weight

Laboratory studies reveal a leukocyte count of 8.5 x 103/mcL (reference range: 4.5–11.0 x 103/mcL) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h (reference range: 0–15 mm/h). Ultrasonography of the right hip reveals increased fluid within the joint. Radiographs of the hips reveal no abnormalities. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This otherwise healthy child presents with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection as well as hip pain and a limp for the past 24 hours, the combination of which suggests transient synovitis (TS). On exam, the right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated, a common finding in patients with hip pain as this position decreases joint capsule tension and the resulting pain. Holding the hip in this position may result in other findings on osteopathic structural examination (e.g., hypertonic hip extensors, decreased range of motion of the affected joint). Patients with TS typically present with no (or low-grade) fever and normal laboratory findings (e.g., normal WBC count and ESR). TS can manifest with unilateral or bilateral joint effusion on ultrasonography, unlike septic arthritis, in which joint effusion is almost always a unilateral finding.

TS is a mild, self-limited disease and treatment is conservative with NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) and rest. If the effusion and/or the hip pain fails to resolve, follow-up imaging should be obtained to reassess for other conditions (e.g., Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease).

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) are typically older than this patient, presenting at about 10–16 years of age. Additionally, SCFE occurs most often in obese boys. Exam findings would also likely reveal external rotation along with flexion at the hip, not just external rotation and abduction. X-ray would show sclerotic epiphysis with joint widening when radiographic changes begin, but might be normal for the initial 4–6 months, meaning imaging alone is not enough to exclude SCFE in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is commonly seen in young patients who present with insidious-onset hip pain that may fluctuate with activity and a limp. X-ray findings may be normal in early disease and in later disease show medial joint space widening and an area of radiolucency around the femoral head indicative of subchondral fracture (crescent sign). While early LCPD cannot be entirely excluded, the patient's recent upper respiratory tract infection and the acute onset of symptoms make another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has a recent infection, making him susceptible to septic arthritis of the hip. However, the index of suspicion for septic arthritis should be low in this case because the patient is able to bear weight and has normal vital signs and laboratory studies. Furthermore, a patient with septic arthritis of the hip would present with exquisite hip pain on palpation and the skin over the affected joint would be warm and erythematous.

E) INCORRECT:

Although osteomyelitis of the hip or femur can manifest with pain and limping, the affected area is typically tender and warm to palpation. In children, osteomyelitis also usually affects the long-bone metaphysis rather than the joints, which would be more likely affected in infants. Laboratory findings usually include an elevated WBC count and ESR. X-ray often shows no abnormalities during the first few days of infection but may reveal periosteal bone deposition.
questions.hint: This patient's effusion will likely improve over the next couple of weeks.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother because of a 2-week history of right hip pain. His mother reports that he has been limping, and the pain worsens with walking. The pain radiates to his right knee. He has not had fever, cough, or runny nose. On examination, there is restricted internal rotation and pain with flexion and abduction of the right hip. He has a right-sided antalgic gait. Laboratory studies show: hemoglobin 137 g/L (115–155), white blood cell count 7.9 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), and platelet count 185 × 109/L (130–380). Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is characterized by posterior and inferior displacement of the femoral epiphysis and can manifest with hip pain, referred knee pain, a restricted range of internal rotation of the hip, and an antalgic gait. Although acute presentations of SCFE (which are associated with < 3 weeks of symptoms) can occur, they are usually associated with trauma. Most presentations of SCFE are chronic and manifest with vague, intermittent symptoms across several weeks to months. Moreover, SCFE is most commonly seen in obese children who are 10–16 years of age.

B) CORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head and is due to rapid epiphyseal growth without adequate blood supply. LCPD most commonly manifests in boys 4–10 years of age with limping (due to a restricted range of internal rotation and abduction of the hip), and pain of the hip and/or upper leg, sometimes referred to the knee, often exacerbated by internal rotation. This condition typically has an insidious onset and is not associated with fever or hematologic abnormalities. Its underlying pathophysiology is not fully understood, but it is likely multifactorial, arising from a combination of repetitive mechanical stress, microtrauma, and genetic predisposition.

See "Differential diagnosis of pediatric hip pain" table.

Key learning point: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children aged 4–10, presenting with insidious hip pain, limp, and restricted hip motion without systemic symptoms or laboratory abnormalities.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Both femoral epiphyses show flattening (blue lines) and sclerosis with areas of fragmentation (examples indicated by arrows).

The appearance is consistent with avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphyses of the femoral heads.

C) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by immune-mediated synovial inflammation and can involve the hip, which results in pain. However, pain associated with JIA is characteristically worse early in the morning and improves with activity during the day. This patient's pain is exacerbated by walking. In addition, JIA is typically associated with intermittent fever and elevated inflammatory markers, including leukocyte count.

D) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is characterized by inflammation of the hip joint capsule and is a common cause of acute hip pain among children (peak incidence of 3–8 years of age). However, this condition is typically associated with a recent viral infection. This patient has no evidence of current or recent infection (no fever, cough, runny nose, or leukocytosis). In addition, symptoms of transient synovitis generally improve within 24 hours and resolve within 2 weeks.

E) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is characterized by abnormal development of the acetabulum, which results in hip instability, hip pain, and a restricted range of abduction. However, this condition typically becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Late findings, which can be seen in children ∼ 18 months of age, include leg length discrepancy and a waddling or a Trendelenburg gait.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition may have unremarkable pelvic radiographs in the first 3–6 months after onset. Early changes include joint space widening, sclerosis of the femoral head, and disparate femoral head sizes.
